subtitle: Place your advance order now on Amazon for the very first volume of the New Thinking
Allowed Dialogue series, Is There Life After Death?
Publication date is June 1st.
Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today, we are going to explore the nature of trance.
With me is Adam Crabtree, who is a psychotherapist
and a trainer of psychotherapists based in
Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
He is the author of From Mesmer to Freud,
Magnetic Sleep and the Roots of Psychological
Healing.
He is also the author of Evolutionary Love
and the Ravages of Greed, as well as Memoirs
of a Trance Therapist.
Welcome Adam.
Thank you.
It's a pleasure to be with you once again.
I have to think that trance is one of the main themes of your whole career.
As I look at your writings, I didn't even
mention your book, Trance Zero, which is breaking
the spell of conformity.
Yes.
Another important book about the nature of trance.
It's something that's fascinated you throughout your professional career.
Well, it really has.
When I was in psychotherapy myself, my therapist
used hypnosis with me, so I became familiar
with it from that side.
In the whole time that I've practiced as a psychotherapist, I've always used hypnosis
and I've come to look upon it as one particular kind of trance.
Trance is the broader word.
It's the older word and it's the one I've come to prefer, actually.
It's a word that's often used in many other contexts.
Yes, it is.
I mean, we talk about being entranced by a beautiful woman or entranced by theatrical
production.
That's right.
It's used in many contexts and it also is often
used in connection with unusual experiences
of consciousness.
And of course, when you're working as a psychotherapist,
that's a big part of its use in psychotherapy
that you're able to tap parts of the psyche that may not be that available otherwise.
So I suppose, just as a first step, we would
say a trance state is an altered state of
consciousness.
Yes.
It is an altered state of consciousness in
the sense that Charlie Tart devised the word.
And it's a good way to look at it as an altered
state of consciousness because that's very
general.
I see trance very general in its meaning.
The meaning of trance for me is a state of focus
on something which brings about a diminished
awareness of everything else, which then evokes
from the person inner resources to deal with
whatever it is that the focus is on.
And that is kind of the essence of how I see trances in its definition.
Well, let me ask you this.
Based on that definition, it strikes me there
may be never an occasion when we are not in
a trance.
Well, that's the way I look at it.
I think that everyday life is made up of moving
from trance to trance, and sometimes trance
is nestled within trance.
Our life is full of different ways that we focus on something and then move to another
focus.
And when you are focused on something, you really cut down on peripheral awareness and
concentrate on that thing.
It strikes me that in Vedic or Hindu philosophy,
when they say, all is Maya, everything is
an illusion, I suspect maybe what they're trying to get at is that we are always in
one form of trance or another.
Maybe they are.
I really don't know how to define it, but you know a lot more about that than I do.
Well, not really, Adam.
I'm speculating.
All right.
All right.
I am.
Because I can't put myself back there with the ancient Vedic sages very well.
They may have had something quite different in mind.
But I have heard people like Charlie Tart, to
whom you referred and who was a good friend
of mine who has been on this program, seated in that very chair where you are.
I think he sometimes uses it that way.
That makes a certain amount of sense, yes.
To me, life is so rich.
It's so full of different inputs that we have
to be able to limit them at any particular
moment in order to deal with it.
Well, okay.
Fair enough.
But then, if we're always in a trance, how is the word meaningful to distinguish one
trance from another?
Well, that's something that I thought about when I wrote my book, Trance Zero.
This was a problem that I was up against.
The other problem was the definition of
trance, which I'll get to a little bit later.
I mean, the implications of the definition.
But yes, how are we going to talk about trance
if it's everywhere and it's a part of life
all the time?
Does that remove any sense of meaning?
Does it become meaningless if we make it so universal?
I don't think we do, because the definition of
it is very specific, so it has a real meaning.
But I found it used to distinguish between
different kinds of trances, to help our thinking
about it, and to sort of describe how it is with us in everyday life.
So the four different kinds of trances that I decided to use in discussing trance is,
first of all, a situational trance, where what we're focused on is a situation where
we're doing something, a project, an undertaking of some kind of action.
And what we have diminished awareness of is
anything else, anything outside of that project
or that action.
Typically like going to a movie.
Going to a movie, that's a very good example,
by the way, because we certainly go into pretty
deep trance in movies sometimes.
Going to a movie, also like dancing, acting, building a cabinet.
We have to focus there too.
So all of these things involve projects and
doing, and I call those situational trances.
The second kind of trance that I speak about
is interpersonal trance, where what we're
focused on is another person and our relationship
with that person, and the communications and
interactions that are happening within that relationship with that person.
I call that interpersonal trance.
The third kind of trance is an inner mind trance.
An inner mind trance means focusing on our inner world.
The world of inner impressions, of memories,
of symbols, of dreams, anything that impresses
us inside and that we have a kind of
emotional mental experience of on the inside.
Daydreaming might be a good example.
Daydreaming would be a very good example,
and night dreaming is the deepest inner mind
trance we can have.
Meditation is a kind of inner mind trance,
and hypnosis is too, and I'll be talking about
that in a moment, how that's a special kind of inner mind trance.
The fourth kind of trance is group mind trance,
where what we're focused on is the thinking
and feeling and attitude of a group that we are engaged in at the moment.
This can be a group like a family group.
It can be, let's say, a church gathering.
It also can be such a thing as a soccer game,
where you're very much focused on a group
feeling, and also, there are unfortunate
instances of this, like crowds and mobs that
do harm.
The madness of the crowd.
The madness of the crowd, exactly.
So group mind trance, and for me, the broadest
group mind trance is the cultural trance,
where that's a group mind trance for a whole culture, a whole people.
Well, I recall attending the American Anthropological
Association meetings in San Francisco, I think
it was back in 1975, when Charles Muses presented
a paper there suggesting that hypnotic trance
was the basis of all acculturation.
That's how we learn language.
That's how we understand who our parents are,
and what they expect of us, and the values
of our society.
It's all learned, according to Muses, through the, I mean, he was quite specific.
It's very much akin to hypnosis.
Yes, and Charlie Tart talks about this, too, in his book, Waking Up, I think it is.
The trance of a whole culture, and he would
talk about being indoctrinated into this trance
from birth.
Maybe from before birth, but at least from
birth, we're indoctrinated in it, and we learn
it very well, and so we don't even realize we're in a trance.
We don't realize that our view of the world
is really very narrow when you think of other
possible cultural views that there are.
It strikes me that this becomes very evident
when you encounter an individual who clings
to a certain idea with enormous certainty, and it's an illogical idea, and you can try
and point out the illogic of it, but it makes no difference.
They're immovable.
Yes, that's right.
We are involved in various ways of sort of making the world understandable, but very
often in the process, we have to reduce it to less than it is, and we stay with that
because it feels familiar, and it feels a safe way of looking at things.
I know social psychologists have pointed out one
of the strongest findings of social psychology
is that when somebody clings to an ideology
or a theory, all the facts that they see seem
to fit that theory, and somehow they manage to ignore all the facts that can be right
under their nose that are contrary to the theory.
That's right.
This happens everywhere.
It happens, obviously, in culture.
It happens in politics, and it happens in universities.
It happens in philosophy.
These are all places that illustrate precisely the thing you're talking about.
Well, you referred to Charlie Tartt's book, Waking Up, and that suggests at least the
possibility that there is a state of consciousness that is not a trance state.
Yes.
Well, there are two aspects of that.
One is, I think we always are trying to expand
our awareness and to step back and not be
so narrow in the way you were talking about,
so that we realize there are more cultural
ways of seeing the world than the one that I was born in.
But then there's also a more, you might say,
a more metaphysical way of approaching that,
and thinking of ourselves as having a part of ourselves that's able to step back from
everything, from all of our trances, almost like a, I suppose some would call it a kind
of witness self, that gets the broadest possible
view and can relate all of our trances to
each other from that kind of perspective.
Well, and I suppose even then, there are more and more subtle levels.
The great illusion may be to think that you actually have awakened.
Yes, that's true.
Yes, I don't know that you could ever completely awaken.
Well, this is a fascinating topic, and now you were going to address the implications
of your definition.
Yes, that's right.
The problem was in 1993, or 1997, when I published Trance Zero.
I tried to figure out how to define trance,
and I came up with the definition we've been
talking about.
But the thing is that hypnosis was, of course,
the word that was mainly being used, and is
mainly being used to describe trance states.
When people write about it, the way I was talking about it, that's too narrow.
It's much broader than just hypnosis, because
hypnosis is something people think of as using
in psychotherapy, stage hypnotism and so forth, special instances of it.
And also, hypnosis is the word that has been
used to study experimentally people in those
particular kinds of altered states.
And I saw there, as I was trying to figure out how to talk about it, a problem.
Because there was no generally agreed upon definition of hypnosis.
Many different definitions, but no one even
claimed to have the final definition of what
it was.
Well, I suppose that's due to the fact that if
hypnosis or trance is a state of consciousness,
my state of consciousness is not observable to anybody but me.
That's true.
That's true.
So, if you're going to define hypnosis, you
have to make it such a broad definition that
it can fit everyone.
Now, when I was trying to see how hypnosis had been defined, I realized that over the
ages, over the 200 years or more, since animal
magnetism and magnetic sleep was discovered.
Franz Anton Mesmer.
That's right.
That hypnosis was labeled, the label was used
a few decades later, that over that period
of time, hundreds of phenomena had been associated with these states.
Very unusual phenomenon.
That's right.
Many of them were unusual.
We would call some of them certainly paranormal,
others more everyday, or others would be just
unusual since they don't happen very often.
Many, many different kinds of phenomena were discussed over that period of time.
And what had happened is that those who were
trying to experiment and understand hypnosis
from an experimental and objective point of
view, in using a definition of hypnosis, had
arrived at the solution of saying certain phenomena will be the defining phenomena
for hypnosis.
And if we're going to study it, then if those
phenomena are present, then we have hypnosis.
And if those phenomena are not present, we can't say we have hypnosis.
And they also talk about the stages or the depth of the trance.
That's right.
That's right.
They would talk about stages and depth.
And there were various ways of defining if a person was in trance, and there were ways
of defining how to go into a trance, what the induction should be.
I found that very unsatisfying because a list
of phenomena can't be a definition of anything.
And one of the problems is that those lists
were chosen by experimenters in a very arbitrary
way.
So hundreds of phenomena, maybe a half a dozen
or at the most 10, were chosen as those which
would be a sign of the real presence of hypnosis.
But they didn't have to be the same 10 or the same 5.
It could vary.
So it seems like a very slippery concept here.
So what I wanted to do was to define it.
And so I used trance, as I've been talking
about it here, and saw hypnosis as one species
of inner mind trance.
The trance where we go inside and become aware of the inner world.
Hypnosis being one species of that, being defined by me as an inner mind trance with
rapport.
That is, it differs from meditation, for instance, which is an inner mind trance.
But there is no rapport with another person.
With hypnosis, there's a rapport.
So it's both inner mind and interpersonal.
Yes.
That's right.
It's interpersonal also.
So it involves someone that we have this connection
with, a person who is either inducing it in
us or inducing it and guiding us through some
process, whatever it may be, like in psychotherapy.
So that was my definition of hypnosis.
And that's a very definite definition, doesn't
depend on any lists, doesn't depend on any
particular phenomenon.
It just depends upon being able to identify
the person as being in the inner world, focused
there and with a diminished awareness of everything else.
Now that definition is one of the reasons
that I decided that something had to be done
about a new definition, was something that had
been written by one of the main hypnotizing
or I should say hypnotic experimenters, whose name was Andrei Reitsenhofer.
And he wrote in around the year 2000, he said
that hypnosis, the field of hypnosis is an
increasing state of chaos.
It's becoming more and more chaotic.
And later on, he says the reason for that, he tells us why he would say that.
He says, we don't know what hypnosis is.
And he came to that conclusion when he was trying to explain to people what kind of an
induction they should use.
How do you induce hypnosis?
He said, well, we don't know what it is.
So you can't define what would be a definitely effective induction.
What you should use is just those that have been shown to work.
Well, it sounds to me like what Reitsenhofer was saying is not so much that
hypnosis itself is chaotic, but that the study of hypnosis.
That's exactly what he was saying.
He was saying the field is chaotic.
And he, as I read this, I thought he was sort
of upset by this and he didn't see any answer
for this.
And I thought that precisely what was needed
was a definition and which I came up with.
Of course, the whole field of consciousness
studies suffers from a certain amount of chaos
as well.
Yes, that's true.
Chaos is, I suppose, just part of the human condition.
As we studied the psyche, you have to, because
you never can contain it, because you never
can bring it down to a final framework or analysis, there has to be a certain amount
of chaos there.
But the chaos in the field of hypnosis, in my opinion, had not been recognized.
People were satisfied with lists, which
can't be satisfactory for experimental work.
And I thought that that needed to be corrected.
Well, I would think the interesting thing
about the study of hypnosis and trance states
is how far can you push it?
Can you use the hypnotic trance to set new records, for example, in track and field?
Because records are being set every year.
They're new records.
Why, I'm pretty sure lots of sports psychologists do exactly that.
Well, absolutely.
And there you're touching upon that aspect of the definition of trance, which is, it
evokes resources needed to deal with whatever it is you're focusing on.
So if you take athletes, what they're focusing
on is better and better athletic performance.
And if they go into a trance, it evokes whatever
resources they may have that are needed for
that, and it helps to enhance those resources,
if you can do this in a very concentrated,
organized way.
So it is very useful for athletes.
And you know, I'm thinking of religious practices
when people pray, when they chant and engage
in various religious rituals.
That also engenders a trance state.
It does.
meditation, concentration on ideals, thinking about the moral life.
These all bring about trance states for us.
That's right.
And there's a certain danger to that.
When I was a graduate student in criminology,
one of my professors was Dr. Bernard Diamond,
who was a psychiatrist and who hypnotized Sirhan
Sirhan after the murder of Robert Kennedy.
And he concluded that Sirhan had put himself into a trance.
And that's what enabled him to commit an act of murder.
Well, that makes sense to me.
He would have to be, if he was going to carry
this out, he would have to go into a state
where he was focused and could proceed in a
logical way towards the goal that he had in mind.
Yeah.
And then, of course, we have the movie, The
Manchurian Candidate, another example of the
potential negative implications of trance.
Trance can be used in any way, negative or positive.
In itself, it just refers to a particular kind of state.
But the use of it is determined by the individual or the group.
I can say that throughout my life, ever since
I was in high school, I learned how to put
myself into a hypnotic trance state and use it to take exams and for general health and
relaxation and looking back now over more than half a century, I would say it served
me very well.
Yes.
And I'm just curious to know, how did you find out about it and how did you know to
do that?
Well, in my case, I had a cousin, Stuart Cohn,
may he rest in peace, and who was an amateur
magician.
Okay.
And he learned it somehow in the course of his amateur magical practice.
And studying stage hypnosis, perhaps, from magicians who would use it.
Yeah.
Mentalists.
It's quite amazing the things that mentalists will do on stage.
Yes.
Yes.
That's right.
So that's the way you learned it.
Yeah.
Yeah.
I consider myself fortunate in that regard to have discovered such a powerful tool at
such a young age.
Absolutely.
You know, and one thing that that reminds me of is I'm a psychotherapist and I teach
people to use hypnosis or trance states in therapy because I use it all the time and
I think it's a very, very powerful thing to use.
What I'm surprised about is so few people in the field use it because I've found it
so incredibly powerful in uncovering things,
in helping people to find their strength,
in developing towards goals they want to reach.
And in my opinion, it's quite neglected in the psychotherapeutic field.
Well, I think you're right.
As I recall, it wasn't until 1954, nearly 200 years after Mesmer, before the American
Medical Association recognized hypnosis as a legitimate practice within medicine.
Well, that very recent has been around for a long, long time.
Yeah.
And even Freud, who learned hypnosis in his early practice, discarded it.
Yes.
That's right.
And that has to do with the attitude of therapists who often followed Freud.
Without doubt.
Without doubt.
His decision not to use it, I'm sure, influenced
the whole tradition after him in psychoanalysis.
Yes.
And I guess that there was a certain amount
of concern that people who practice hypnosis
had an uncanny power like Svengali or Rasputin that made people a little afraid.
Yeah.
And those are just myths.
That's not the way hypnosis or trance states are at all.
But those kinds of things have been projected
on it because it's been mysterious to people.
And we project onto mysterious things all of our, let's say, fears and will that way
distort what that thing may be.
Yeah.
But nevertheless, there must be thousands of hypnosis practitioners.
Oh, yes.
I'm sure that there are many thousands of them.
Actually, many people today are being trained
to use hypnosis, not so much in psychotherapy,
but in little projects like giving up smoking, losing weight.
It's also being used as a part of past life exploration, that sort of thing.
Many people are being trained to do that.
For me, that is just a very small part of the power of hypnosis.
And I like to train people to use it for the deepest things.
Yeah.
You know, to me, one of the most profound
uses of the trance state is to help condition
oneself in terms of self-esteem.
And I would go even further and to say self-love for oneself.
So often, we get into bad habits in which we, in effect, attack ourselves.
Through the use of hypnotic trance, we can correct that habit.
Yes.
This is very true.
I agree with that.
One of the things that hypnosis does is it
puts you in touch with your inner resources,
and that increases your self-esteem.
Now that leads towards the subject of human potential development and human potential
movements.
Where I believe hypnosis or trance states have been sort of instinctively chosen as
an essential part of developing human potentials,
whether that human potential movement was
back with Puisiger in the very beginning of all this, or in the 60s, when there was an
opening up of awareness of and interest in
human potentials, and a realization that those
potentials were far beyond what perhaps had been thought.
So what I have seen in the study of those times, and right up to now, is that most of
the techniques used in human potential seminars,
groups, exploratory projects of various kinds
involve trances in a central way.
Yeah.
I mean, we hear the term, for example, guided meditation.
Yes.
Yes.
It sounds like a trance state.
Very definitely.
It's a trance state.
But there's a difference, I guess, between
doing something like that, where you're setting
your intention to do something positive for
yourself, as opposed to sitting down in front
of the television and watching the news every
night at six o'clock, and getting entranced
by all of the horrible things that are going on in the world.
Yes.
That is true.
And certainly, those are trances.
We go into trances when we watch television without any question.
And it can become an addiction, because a
trance can become, a repeated trance can become
an addiction.
And it can, in that case, be an addiction that actually interferes with one's mood,
and with feelings about life, and so forth.
Yes.
So, I guess the lesson in all of this is that
we do have the opportunity and the ability
to choose, to some extent at least, which kind of a trance we're going to be in.
We do.
We are free human beings, and we have the ability to use that freedom to make choices
about which trances we will go into.
We are going to go into trances willy-nilly,
but we can choose which they will be, to some
extent.
I've actually come to see emotional illnesses
or emotional disturbances as trance clusters,
where we're in a certain set of trances that
keep coming and repeating themselves over
and over again, and we can't see beyond that cluster.
And so, we're very narrowed into them, and particularly when that involves such things
as a lack of good feeling about oneself, or
it involves fears or uncontrollable emotions,
that's the very nature of emotional disturbances.
Well, if I'm caught up in an emotional disturbance
like that, I suppose one way to break through
is just maybe to take a deep breath or something to kind of shift your attention.
Well, yes, that can help, but for many people,
those clusters are so coherent that once they
take hold, it's very hard to break out of them.
And here's where therapeutic work can help
them, but they might also develop a specific
technique for themselves that does break through for them.
For many, it's really difficult, though, to get caught in those clusters.
Sure.
Well, some problems are much more severe than others.
Yes, that's right.
And surely, psychotherapy, I think, is something
that everybody can and ought to benefit from.
In a way, it's a shame that it's become sort of
captured by the medical model and the insurance
companies and...
Yes, that is a shame, because it reduces human beings to more things than persons.
I think that psychotherapy should be the great
advocate for human beings as rich, deep, and
sacred persons, and to respect that and to help people free themselves from whatever
it is that's causing them not to be what they can be.
Well, Adam Crabtree, once again, what an enlightening discussion.
Thank you for being with me.
You're certainly welcome.
I've enjoyed it very much.
And thank you for being with us.
